cons: They have a new pay scale, and even someone with 38 years of nursing exp is not allowed to be at the top of the scale. Does someone have to be dead or 90 years old? Nursing is a womens profession and Scripps values the doctors greatly, even when they treat others badly. Double standards. 22 top executives with the highest pay, 80% of which are men. Scripps is behind the times with innovative business ways. They like to re invent the wheel yearly. This will keep younger professionals/RN's out of the industry for sure.

job_title: Registered Nurse in San Diego, CA
pros:
Convenient commute. 
Level 1 trauma center experience
cons:
There's "on call" everywhere, but there is way too much call requirement here. No work/life balance.
There is a massive employee exodus happening now. Many nurses and various techs are bolting for the door and finding employment at other hospitals like Kaiser and UCSD. Management has not even acknowledged the severity of the issue, they just burry their heads in the sand and pretend everything is OK.
Nobody is accountable, ever. It's like "The Wild West", completely lawless, and at times reckless. People do what they want, when they want.
Among "old timers" people employed more than 20 years, there is a pervasive sense of outright laziness. They "put their time" in, worked hard in 2002 and now want points for simply showing up to punch a clock.
Management never addresses bigger issues, but overmanages insignificant minutia.
Employees are leaving at a much faster rate than they can be replaced, in some departments, 2-3/week, other departments more than 75% of staff are newly hired and some of them already looking to exit also.
Very little sense of camaraderie.

job_title: Patient Care Representative in La Jolla, CA
pros: The patients. Most are really good people who want to get better and for the most part, treat you the worker, extremely well.
cons:
The coworkers. Most of them are horrible: the management, the doctors, the PA’s, the MA’s, pretty much everyone backstabs everyone.

Management caves to whoever yells the most. I worked with one woman who everyone was scared of, so she got to abuse me, pick her schedule, manipulate patients etc. Management does not have your back nor do they care about you. I left a company that I thought didn’t care about me, and went to a company that cared even less.

Scripps committed wage theft by not paying me my first full paycheck because they claimed I didn’t work all the days that I worked because the first week orientation where you learn about how information is store and shared, so some of that time was studying for exams at the end of that week. Once, you’re employed, whether you are “working” or not, legally, you have to be paid or it’s wage theft. Keep in mind this was at the beginning of the pandemic and they were short changing their workers. If you think I’m being dramatic, after I quit, I received two class action lawsuit checks for the same wage theft claims that were committed by scripps to other workers. 

They promised me a raise after three months, it never happened.

Also, when someone got demoted there was an earlier schedule which was not offered to me but instead given to the new hire who just started their first week on the job. Keep in mind, the woman who treated me like I was subhuman, who picked her schedule, was not an official schedule because the manager was buddies with her, so he let her do whatever she wanted. If the one lady got seniority, why didn’t I?

Management are backstabbers. One lady was applying for a promotion and my co-worker asked if the lady was going to get the promotion and my manager laughed and told her “are you kidding me?”

The good news is the company is struggling and failing, so hopefully all these managers get fired because that’s what they deserve.

review_title: Nepotism,  and Incompetence and Vengeful Leaders
job_title: Trainer in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits, living in San Diego
cons:
Working at this organization, I had the pleasure and unfortunate experience of working in both the clinical and the IS departments. If you are planning on working for a clinical area within the system, Scripps is amazing. If you are looking to work for IS, RUN!
 The IS department is run on nepotism. I have never worked in such a toxic work environment. The toxicity stems from the people in the top of IS. Any solution you submit for process improvement are usually seen as a threat to leadership and you will be castigated. 

I brought up the fact a colleague was doing something wrong that would put people in danger, this person came back and told leadership that I had farted purposely (not sure how one does that) in the middle of a conversation. Leadership was more concerned about my alleged flatulence than this persons actions that put people in danger. 

Although I had stellar reviews from students and my yearly evaluations my supervisors noted I was proactive, contributed positively, and was overall a “joy” to get along with, I was held up to move back into a similar job I held pervious role within the clinical areas. Yet people with less skill and experience passed me by because they knew they needed to kiss the right butts. 

When I asked how I could improve, I was told I needed to be like able. Noting my evaluations spoke well of my like-ability, I was told, “this is exactly what I am talking about, the right people don’t like you”.

The culture of nepotism and like-ability being more important than job ability (yes that was actually said at an employee meeting), is exactly why this organization was recently prey to a malware attack. It’s mostly full of incompetence. 

Additionally, when I started with the hospital, the orientation was about Ellen Browning Scripps and the Sisters of Mercy and how Scripps Mercy came to be. Meetings were always about the mission statement. In the two years I worked for IS, the only thing ever mentioned at large meetings was EBITDA, I never heard the mission statement from leadership at any single meeting. 

If you don’t have experience this is a good place to get it, but get out once you have attained what you need. Most people do this and as a result, this organization has paid for a lot of certifications people take elsewhere because the working environment is so unbelievably toxic. I quite this job and work for one of the top hospitals in the country. They value my skills, pleasant demeanor and the fact that I don’t kiss butt.

job_title: ICU RN in La Jolla, CA
pros: Educational benefits, some of the staff are wonderful, real team players.  Depending which hospital and which department you work in whether you will have a good experience or a truly terrible one.  Green Hospital, Encinitas and Chula Vista facilities are much friendlier.  They do have a great internship program for new nurses.  It's a good place to get experience and then look for a job somewhere else.
cons: Nursing at Scripps Prebys in the ICU is stressful and sometimes feels unsafe.  HR and the managers don't care because if anything goes wrong than the nurses are the ones thrown under the bus.  Impossible to do all that you're expected and there is no help.  Very cliquish.  The ICU in many of the Scripps system used to have a good mix of new to very experienced nurses.  Now most people leave after a year or two.   Maybe it's this way at all hospitals but Scripps really did use to be different.  Now managers and administration is more concerned about their bonuses and raises than running a safe hospital.  I worked in the ICU at 2 of the Scripps hospitals (occasional shifts at the others) for 8 years, the ICU has gotten progressively more stressful.  So stressful that probably 75% of the nurses that I've worked with in the ICU have left within the last 2 years for either other departments at Scripps or to other hospital ICUs.  All of us who left wonder why we didn't do so earlier.

review_title: Healthcare? Scripps, not Healthy Work Environment. Management doesn't Care.
job_title: Registered Nurse in La Jolla, CA
pros: I love being a nurse and that helped me endure the ugly politics. Read all the reviews. You will see a theme.
cons:
Read all the reviews on this site. The same theme. 
BAD management.

Corporate culture of bullying, retaliation and targeting employees. 
You will NEVER get fair treatment once targeted.

After 16 years, I have found a healthy Department in the Scripps System. Many of us are "refugees" who fled other Departments. Don't waste 16 years of your life.  I know of nurses from 6 other Departments in the system that experienced what I wrote below. I have worked in numerous Departments and have found 2 that are functional. 

There is NO protection. No union and I am not even big on Unions.

Every Refugee has same story. Toxic work environments. You can tell which Departments are the worst because they have jobs posted week after week.

We fled departments that had the following. Lazy team, Management missing and playing favorites, if you speak up you will be Written up. Double standards.Catering to MDs and not backing nurses.


True story. MD didn't know computer charting, refused to use the help line for assistance, delayed patient care because no orders and the nurse was harassed by Management because the doctor complained about the nurse. Turn the table. If nurse showed up and didn't know basic requirement of the job, I doubt anyone would ever suggest it was somehow the doctor who was the problem.

Toxic, toxic, toxic.

Scripps cares about their employees and their community, and that means something.

review_title: Great Team of Healthcare Professionals, BUT...
job_title: Registered Nurse in San Diego, CA
pros: Great Team to work with. Care Management Team rounding on the acute floors (even in non-teaching hospitals) really encourage a collaborative work environment between all staff members providing patient care. Patient-centered care, but in a way that empowers the healthcare providers. Doctors respect and trust the nursing staff. Pharmacy, rehab, housekeeping, etc. are great to work with. Awesome programs that enable nurses to train into specialty floors. Great new grad program that treats its members like real assets and invests in them by providing a strong foundation to build their nursing practice upon.
cons: Management is stagnant. They need to stop placing yes people in management positions and instead hire people who understand the concept of leadership, accountability, and vision. I've seen good nurses with management experience and a great educational background get passed over for management positions because the leadership already in place would rather hire someone they personally liked, even if that person was horribly underqualified. Scripps needs to learn how to choose its leadership. Upper echelon hospital administration also is too worried about themselves, their bonuses, and their donors instead of focusing on the needs of the employees.

review_title: Scripps Health - A Good Health System to Work for in San Diego
job_title: Senior Director in San Diego, CA
pros:
One of the best reasons is the location.  However, Scripps is also beginning to have a national reputation for forward thinking.  The CEO is very competent.  Their compensation is fair for a health care system.  Leadership's committment to communicating with managers and above is tremendous for an organization of it's size.  Most employees I dealt with had strong moral.

Scripps is also becoming the dominant healthcare organization in the San Diego region.

Scripps recognizes that work is not everything and goes to great lengths to ensure that employee satisfaction is monitored.  Executive bonus payments are in part based on employee satisfaction scores.
cons:
Almost all meaningful decisions are made at the senior executive level.  There are very opportunities to participate in decision making, even as a senior director or vice president.  

Like most large organizations, there are competing factions within Scripps Health that vy for influence with senior leadership.  This internal competition seems to be almost encouraged by the CEO.  As a result, there is a culture of secrecy and "scheming" among the senior executives.

There are limited opporunities for advancement.  Most leadership positions are held by individuals who are long entrenched and will not be moving on soon.  Also, Scripps has a history of hiring from the outside to fill leadership positions.

review_title: Distrust between management and clinical team
job_title: Medical Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Insurance is great. Love the job as part of the nursing team. I like most of my coworkers and you can tell which nurses actually like their job. The clinical staff is pulling all they can together. Doctors are great to work with.
cons: The pay isn't  competitive. But the worse is the management is doing a pretty bad job and one of many reasons are 1) they're too busy sucking up on each other to even pay attention to what the departments need 2) No transparency and poor communication. The clinical team is being spread too thin, always under-staffed and yet they keep adding more work and expectations to the nurses without any help which starts creating stress between nurses. It's too bad but we're losing more good nurses because of the management. The good nurses know when to leave because they see the politics that the management is playing.

review_title: So relieved to have left Scripps
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Encinitas, CA
pros: Medical, Dental, Vision health benefits
cons:
- No holiday pay, no sick pay, everything is taken out of your PTO. 

- Rude coworkers, managers and supervisors do not support you. Scripps does not have a policy in place for workplace bullying.

- Multiple responsibilities in one position.  You will find yourself doing 7 or 8 different jobs even though you were hired to do one job. 

- Low wages.

- No bonuses. 

- Scripps seems to have budget problems all the time which results in lay offs or benefits terminating.

- It was hard to get the day off or leave early. Every time I requested time off my supervisor would try and negotiate the day and recommend to change it to another day. She had no respect with my time off requests as if my life outside of work did not matter. 

- The department I worked in was always understaffed. There is a high turn over rate, people were always resigning after a short amount of time. It was stressful doing my job and the job of two to three other people because there was never enough people.

review_title: Overall Scripps Health was a better than average company to work for.
job_title: CT Tech in San Diego, CA
pros: Scripps offered great salaries and benefits packages for full time employees.  It was very easy to accrue a significant amount of PTO, especially if you were frugal about calling in sick.  I requested and always recieved an average of over 4 weeks off a year, for just about every year I worked there.  Twice I took 5 week vacations.  My management was always down to earth and easily approachable.  Your extended leave bank maxed out at 480 hours, so if you ever needed to take a leave of abscence for a medical, mental, or family problem it lasted a long time, since it was combined with State Disability pay and rationed out,  a small amount at a time.  The only medical benefits which seemed somewhat limited was there dental plan, although I have heard that most companies are about the same in this regard.
cons: I had a very specific skills set and was somewhat stuck in a limited supervisoy role for 8 years until I decided to leave. I would have liked to have had the option of leaving that role, at least temporarily and training in a  different modality/area of the department.

job_title: Registered Nurse in La Jolla, CA
pros: Met some really great people there and had excellent clinical experiences from patients. Decent benefits and savings plans and room for improvement.
cons: Does not hire from within even though candidate may be well qualified with the same credentials as other applicants. Poor management particularly with the site based float pool and some play favorites. Hardly any people of color in leadership/ nurse positions and continues to be that way. Nurses know they get treated badly if they are people of color (particularly African American) thus probably the reason I wasn't hired for their new graduate program. Was told more than once from non-black current employees thats why I did not get hired and its unsettling and awful. Managers are not sensitive to this fact clearly. Also, hiring dept never got back to me on how to improve and emails to upper management were ignored.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Encinitas, CA
pros: Competitive pay, opportunities for advancement.
cons: Clinical mentors and charge RNs at night leave a lot to be desired, with very few exceptions. They're supposed to be your support staff, break nurses, etc, but they like to watch from the comfort of their own chair as you run around like a headless chicken. Assignments are supposed to be acuity based, but most days they just group patients based on room proximity to each other. Very high expectations to keep patients and families happy, but management, supervisors, charge, etc like to tell you about all the complaints and roll out new patient care "models" for the nurses and not actually get their hands dirty. Oh yeah, and if you think you're going to get a lunch break and have your patients medicated, you're wrong. Expect to hear "room 250 called asking for pain meds". Gee, thanks.

review_title: Overall a good place, but changing a lot with healthcare reform. Not for the better IMO.
job_title: Lift Technician in Encinitas, CA
pros: Good benefits. They offer things like tuition reimbursement, discounts to restaurants, free or cheap healthcare depending on if your full-time or part-time. Good environment for the most part.
cons: Pay is low and not thought out. For example: someone on the front lines (e.g. CNAs and transporters) directly dealing with patient safety and satisfaction will start off around $12-13. While a person who stocks supply rooms will start off at $15. Doesn't make sense. Can be a political environment at times. Workload was increasing for everyone more and more during my time without any compensation. "Here's more work, yet keep the patients happy and don't make a mistake... oh and get paid the same." Most patients are not too happy for one reason or another (spreading support staff and nurses thin is one reason) and will take it out on anyone with a Scripps badge. But don't get me wrong there are some really nice ones and the ones that make you think "this is why I'm here! To make a difference in peoples lives." Unfortunately there were less of those times than I would have liked.

review_title: A friendly, patient oriented hospital. Most professional level employees are satisfied and comfortable.
job_title: Registered Nurse in La Jolla, CA
pros: Located in a lovely part of San Diego. Easy access via freeway. A nice, clean environment, most people are happily working there for many years. The turon over in general is not very much. Scripps nurses, doctors, respiratory therapists, physicial and occupational therapists, social workers and other professionals strive to do the best for each patient every day. Scripps has always kept up with the compensation package to stay competitive and keep employees happy.
cons: Scripps Health, as an institution is undergoing many changes, some are deleterious to staff. The "workforce" is being thinned and the workload is being increased at all levels in order to save money for the institution. The level of unhappiness is slowly rising throughout and there is a subtle sense of disappointment in administration for doing this. Ultimately it is affecting patient care as the staff is slowly being overworked.

review_title: I would rather have no job then work for Scripps
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits that are left.
cons:
Failing Leadership from the top to middle management.  Those in front of the patients and customers are driven to do more with less.  It's all about money and patient care and services are last.  Senior management is fearful that all of their past and present missteps are bring about the end of Scripps but continue to blame and attack employees.
The HR department is only there for management and employees be damned.  They attack the hard working front line staff and protect  managers, directors, VP's and CEO who are never held accountable.  They are the attack dogs of management and should not be trusted.
The best managers have left due to senior management and HR failures to support them and the lies of employees who complain the most and do the least amount of work.
If you honestly get a Scripps employee to tell you their real feelings, they will tell you they want to leave and they are unhappy.
The Scripps culture is very toxic and if you are not a part of the Senior Management Click you are a target.
I would not recommend this company to anyone.

job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: Direct Managers are very nice and work well with their subordinates on the Information Management side.
cons: On the Operations side not so much. Operations leadership tends to behave disrespectfully and in some cases even become blatantly rude when you do not tell them what they want to hear or are not able to comply with their demands. (Yes, you are not asked, it is demanded from you to do something.) Pay is the lowest compared to other San Diego area hospitals. They tout their 'Great Place to Work" but seem to hide the statistics from the IS side because those scores are extremely low. It is not uncommon to be up all night for several nights during the week and still be expected to work your regular shift the next day.

review_title: Computer charting saves lives and protects your license.
job_title: Registered Nurse in San Diego, CA
pros: i have met some really nice people that work their.  At a few of the hospitals the doctors are good and helpful.  Short drive from my house, and provides me with a paycheck.
cons: Paper charting dates back 10 years, the computer charting portion of the assessment is outdated software when its not frozen its redundant and no one ever looks at it anyways (waste of time) .  The system pays out millions of dollars in bonuses they should use that money to update their charting system.  Medication scanning has proven to save millions of lives why does scripps not pay the CEO his bonus one year and update their system.  The doctors notes are on paper as well as the orders, takes twice as long to read the chicken scratch.  Doctors can be very difficult to get ahold of. Pay is on the low end of the spectrum for southern california systems.

review_title: Contract and temporary hires be warned...
job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: A great atmosphere with plenty of upside in terms of company vision and coworkers who are both helpful and positive.   Although I only had my manager for a few months, she was one of the best that I've ever had in the way of daily interactions with our group.  This outreach was also reflected by managers and directors above my direct supervisor.
cons: The company is bleeding money and this makes any contract position ripe for unexpected release.   In my case, this caused my department training to stall and never allowed me to see my full potential when weighed against employees past or presently employed by Scripps.   I only made it two months out of a six month contract and I should have paid better mind to the fact that my lack of department level meeting inclusion was a bad omen.

review_title: Good salary and benefits but they work you to death.
job_title: Registered Nurse in San Diego, CA
pros: Excellent co-workers, great sense of family on each unit.  Most of the staff pull together to try to help each other out.
cons: Administration is so focused on the bottom line and patient reviews that good patient care despite the obstacles of a poor computer system and chronic understaffing for the patient acuity and turnover is unappreciated by management.

job_title: Coordinator in La Jolla, CA
pros: Good health and other benefits.
cons: I worked for a high ranking leader within the company who had a history of verbally abusing subordinates, and it was well documented as employees often only lasted for a few months under this person. The CEO and other leaders throughout the organization were well aware of this person's leadership pitfalls and seemingly did not like working with nor respect the leader yet did nothing while excellent employees left the company. Also, while the Scripps hospitals have been among the best in the past, my experience as a patient at Scripps Green post surgery was horrendous. That experience coupled with seeing an OBGYN and endocrinologist there that were lacking knowledge and bedside manner, missing a major diagnosis, and notably after 30+ years of solely seeing physicians at Scripps clinics and hospitals, I no longer will consider remaining within the Scripps system of care.

review_title: Do you value your soul? Or your sanity?
job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: Good benefits, better-than-average pay for most positions, hospitals are in good locations and well-kept, great coworkers, Active CEO that actually listens to employees, and is engaged in the day-to-day operations of the company.
cons: I don't even know where to begin. Audit and Compliance department within I.S. is far too powerful. Very political environment, management likes to play favorites, and likes to hire people to jobs that they were unqualified for. Hardly any opportunities for advancement. Too much legacy software (still on Windows XP and Internet Explorer 6) and a cobbled-together IT Infrastructure. Too many middle-managers and directors not doing any of the work. Contractors (especially in IS) are not treated fairly.

job_title: Systems Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros: I had a great work schedule and many IT were able to start early and leave early. Tech wise, running latest and greatest of Citrix infrastructure.
cons: Scripps is in transition and most all of the perks have been taken away. Morale was at an all time low in my department when I left. They are famous for saying "Scripps doesn't lay off" but OH YES THEY DO. They laid off in mass in 2016 and again in 2018. Some managers are better than others, but I wasn't impressed. Many managers (mine included) all about pleasing the higher ups and saving their own jobs. No job stability in my opinion. They laid off hundreds and now hiring again. Messed up.

review_title: High RN Turnover, High Stress, daily OT off the clock
job_title: RN Case Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Well-reputed Hospital, compensation is in the top tier of three big hospital chains in San Diego
cons:
Extremely productivity-orienteed organization. Productivity calculated daily, then all pt. care staff receive weekly email listing productivity of all care providers on the team,  everyone knows who is the fastest and who is not.  Its shaming and hurts morale. 
Managers unsupportive. Everyone is stressed out with high productivity focus.  Most staff working daily overtime off the clock which is necessary for most staff to complete all work and charting from the day. However management warns that this is grounds for termination. Its a no-win situation.
Multiple RN's had to take time off due to stress-related health problems and turnover is high.

review_title: My experience at Scripps has shown me alot about Healthcare, and a part of life that people don't normally see.
job_title: Lift Technician in La Jolla, CA
pros: Scripps has good benefits. If healthcare is what you are in careerwise, it's a great place to learn.
cons: It can be difficult to advance within the organization. The pay, compared to competing hospitals, is low. It's difficult to move up, when you are told that you do not have enough experience. This makes things harder on healthcare proffesionals who have loans to pay back after completion of their education.

review_title: Not the best place, not the worst
job_title: Staff RN in Chula Vista, CA
pros: The people that I work with, the nursing staff and the physicians are some of the best people on earth.  Dedicated, strong and amazing at the amount of crap that they take from literally EVERYONE!  Can't say enough good about them.
cons: The staffing is dangerously low at times and we are expected to just "take it"!  There is just so much making do before something hits the fan, and then the overworked nurse is on her own.  There is no room to work and the equipment is not great.  Lots of paperwork and no good computer charting system.  Unsafe.  The patients are rude, pushy, and demanding and think for whatever reason, they are entitled to make the rules.  And they often do whatever they want, to the detriment of the patients and turning the nursing staff upsidedown.  Have never worked at a place that gives in to demands like this!

job_title: Medical Secretary in La Jolla, CA
pros: health insurance and great coworkers
cons: Everything from Scripps not following their rules,managers and supervisors use employees as pawns and use intimidation tactics to get the job done even if it's at the expense of the employees job,health or mental health capacity. They really do their best to show you that Scripps doesn't even follow their own written rules, managers hold secret meetings and discuss and gossip behind every employees back this has dire negative effects on all including those that don't directly work in the department as gossip is spread and spearheaded by managers without any remorse or real consequences from HR or corporate. Even if the employees does complain it is held over their head like they murdered someone and will forever have to bear the consequences of speaking up when scripps policy itself encourages employees to speak up. Enough is Enough.

job_title: Registered Nurse in San Diego, CA
pros: Employee oriented company. They will watch out for you if you give back to the company. I must say, The most fair company with whom I have ever worked. Not the highest pay, but certainly more than the average for the area.

job_title: Emergency Department RN in San Diego, CA
pros:
Good co-workers, most nurses help each other and most of the doctors are reasonable and nice. Staff goes all out for each other to celebrate life events. 
CEO is an actual person with good ideas who tries very hard and you can contact him and he will respond. There are a lot of good people there who work hard everyday to do good work.
cons: Safety issues from violent patients, need to improve security- need more of them and need to let them do more. Good philosophies from the top sometimes get lost in the middle. High turnover rate. Not a lot of opportunity for advancement from some positions can be discouraging. Some of the policies make no sense financially or otherwise but it is like that everywhere.

review_title: Too many management layers, Zero paid national holidays, Formal dress code.
job_title: Project Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Good job security with no lay-offs, Providers seem to really care about improving patient care, beautiful care facilities, and good healthcare benefits as long as seen by Scripps provider.
cons: Too difficult to enact change with so many middle management layers (leads, supervisors, managers, directors, senior directors, assistant vp, etc.  Benefits not as good as advertised, no 401k match.  Very bureaucratic and political.  Shirt and tie attire for IT organization.

review_title: Significant stagnation in the leadership ranks
job_title: Middle Management in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Scripps Health does have some of the finest clinicians with whom I have had the opportunity to work.  In fact even though I have left the organization I continue to receive my care from Scripps Health because the care is top notch.  This is not because they are necessarily the most state of the art or most cutting edge, there just seems to be a genuine culture of caring imbued in the clinical staff.

Likewise, the many locations spread through San Diego County are enviable.  The weather is nearly always pleasant.

Scripps has also invest heavily in physical infrastructure, especially in La Jolla and to the north.  As a result their workplace facilities are often incredibly new, well-designed, and state-of-the-art.
cons:
I will bring up several themes that other previous reviewers have mentioned.  In many ways I deeply appreciate the visibility that GlassDoor offers, because in hindsight, I can honestly say I was not alone in my feelings, although I was led to believe so.

I read in a previous review that Scripps is very much promotes people "in the same mold" or "do not rock the boat".   Based on my personal experience, I must concur with that assessment.  Although I was hired into a leadership position in SHAS (Scripps Health Administrative Services) from the outside, and told during the interview process my wealth of outside experience would be a great asset to Scripps, I was more often than not told formally and informally by my peers and other leaders that I needed to do more to fit in.  A trusted outside mentor of mine described it best to me when I recounted my predicament to her:  Scripps is a "go along to get along" organization.  Loyalty is valued much more valued as an asset than experience or innovation.   This was antithetical to the very "speak truth to power" leadership culture which had been instilled in me, so at the end of the day, it was a terrible fit. 

Unfortunately it is this "go along to get along" culture that drives opportunities for growth and promotion within the organization.   I can recount numerous times when individuals who were neither the most qualified, most senior, nor most capable were offered promotion time and time again simply because they fit the mold of a Scripps leader.  This is often the worst kept secret in the organization - certain individuals will get promoted because they are well connected while both looking and acting the part of a Scripps Leader, not because their talents or efforts really made them stand apart.    Again, this is probably the worst kept secret in all of Scripps and is often discussed behind the scenes, but is never addressed for fear of professional reprisal.

Lastly, probably the most challenging aspect of working at Scripps was working with my peers.  There is almost a "Survivor" like mentality among the director-level leaders and above at Scripps.  The very low turnover rates among the executive ranks, combined with the vast title inflation in the middle management, creates this Darwinian competition to get any advantage for promotional opportunities.  I personally experienced this behavior, and I saw it time and again happen to others.  Directors see each other not as colleagues, but as competitors, doing all they can to make themselves stand out, usually at the expense of one another.  This created an atmosphere of intrigue and maliciousness I haven't witnessed even in my years in the cutthroat world of publicly-traded companies.  Even for the best intentions, I was routinely thrown under the bus by peers.  Trust is minimal within peer groups, although at leadership gatherings everyone acts like it is all one big happy family.

review_title: Used to be "A Great Place to Work", now, not so much
job_title: ICU RN in La Jolla, CA
pros:
In most cases, the people you work with are wonderful, caring and professional.  Great teamwork between MD's (with one arrogant exception) RN's, RT, PT, OT, dietary and Speech Therapists.  Beautiful view.  Exceptional learning opportunities if you choose to take advantage of them.   Wellness program and benefits (though most not aimed at nursing staff working 12 hr shifts.)
If you are an office person, not a nurse, Scripps is probably still a "Great Place" to work.  Our Nursing Director may be actually trying to turn things around, but it may also be lip service, time will tell..
cons: Productivity and patient satisfaction are so emphasized that the nurses are sometimes stressed to the max.  Some nurses always get a "lighter" or easier assignment, while others seem to always get the more difficult (as in delirious or heavier pts).  We do not have proper staffing nor do we have the proper equipment to take care of our bariatric patients safely.  Most of the ICU RN's are looking for other jobs or a change in career path.  Most of Scripps money seems to be going to it's new cardiovascular center at Memorial while at Green we are told to cut, cut, cut.  Most RN's, except in a few select areas feel overworked and overwhelmed by all the demands.  However, this may be the way healthcare is going and not just a problem at our healthcare system.  Our computer program, Centricity, is the slowest,  most poorly put together EMR that I have used.  In the ICU we still have a paper flow sheet and a paper MAR, besides the computerized one - which is ridiculous.

review_title: Taking from their employees, little by little.
job_title: Transporter in San Diego, CA
pros: Health benefits are great... but with the new HMO plan introduced for 2016, you can get a sense of how they will continue to cut benefits like they have been doing since 2007. PTO (vacation) is awesome... if you get a manager that will ever approve it. PSD (sick pay) is pointless, you need to take 16 hours of PTO before you can use any PSD. (based on 2014 employment) Coworkers... again, awesome... if they aren't stressed by being understaffed with budget cuts and mediocre managment. Education Incentives... best part of Scripps... they will aid you to educate yourself as long as it reflects within careers in scripps (i hope they haven't cut back on this)
cons:
In a nut shell, one of the best companies in the U.S. when I started in 2007. The list that follows is what was taken from hourly employees and what was "added" to Scripps as a company. - All LVNs let go, system wide - Annual Raises Maxium lowered from an average of 4% to an average of 2% - prices in cafeteria doubled - merging of entry level positions [more responsibility, same pay] - raised prices of healthcare benefits from $0 to $25 (2014) a paycheck - closed and liquidated entire clinic not pulling a profit - success shares (basically a christmas bonus for non management employees) reformed to almost impossible standards meaning less than a days pay for some departments.  

As follow is what Scripps added to the company..., 300+ bed cardio unit in la jolla (3mil a bed), new ER, power plant, parking garage to Scripps Mercy in Hillcrest.  CEO salary raise from 1.6mil to 2.1mil annually (numbers rough and based on newspaper report in 2014)

I attended an "Employee 100" meeting for upcoming leaders and there, the CEO and department heads told us that the reason for the various cuts, listed above, was Obamacare.  The CEO stated and I quote, "We have to make the tough decisions for the company to continue."  The only required duty of this course, for this first class, was to relay this info to your departments... misdirection propaganda 101... (and a tough decision to take the raise Sir, very tough)

job_title: Administrative Coordinator in La Jolla, CA

I'm not sure how Scripps earns so many awards. I've approached HR and upper management for help but they don't care. 

Raises and bonuses have come to a halt but Scripps expects employees to take on more job responsibilities. 

The physicians are treated like God's. They have free food catered for all their meals. They are paid a few thousand dollars as incentive for taking mandatory computer training.

review_title: Once the top, financial losses are causing changes.
job_title: Staff RN in La Jolla, CA
pros:
Great benefits. Enjoyment of job depends on specific manager and Department. It is beneficial to know someone on the inside before you decide to work there. Make sure you are getting into a Department with a good Leader. 

Nice patients in a beach community. I really enjoyed the great care and patient ratios when I started at Scripps. It isn't the same.  See Cons.

They offer part-time employment. They have been said to be good employer to workers over age 50 and working moms. 

Each year they give employees a survey where we review Leadership, our Managers and Scripps. I appreciate that and they seem to listen and sometimes make changes.
cons:
Unfortunately, over the past couple of years, I have seen deteriorating situation for nurses. 

Scripps lost money and it is trickling down. 

Heavy patient loads to the point nurse are report them for safety issues. 

Watching the clock and your time cards to the point that it is just easier to punch out and finish work, rather than be counseled on "time-management" after you have been pushed to the limit with heavy, patient assignments. 

There is no Union representation, which many nurses don't want, so I thought, too, but you are not protected.

GO ELSEWHERE. If you are starting your career, go where you can have a long career with protection and great retirement in the end. Go to work for a profitable hospital.  I would go to UCSD, Kaiser or in the Military, where your voice is represented. Benefit and retirement packages are the absolute best and you may be able to retire early. Profitable hospitals don't have such a high incentive to squeeze every ounce of work out of you. This could change in the future, if Scripps gets back on financial footing. 

If you pick a career at Scripps, make sure you are using it as a step along the ladder. At anytime, your manager or Leadership can change and it can be a different situation.

Plain put... as long as you don't try to rock the boat, question the leadership team or make too many suggestions - then you should be fine. I am looking to leave, which is sad.... There is no loyalty to long term employees. It is no secret that Scripps recently laid off over 100 employees and most of them had over 15 to 20 years of service to the organization.

review_title: Layoffs are coming in '14, career ending, culture of bullying, low pay
job_title: Developer in San Diego, CA
pros:
There are a few, very good people in IT that are stuck in this world of hell. I hope they can get out as soon as possible.

I don't know what the hospital side looks like but the administration portion is a mess. There are grumblings by doctors that they feel disrespected by administration.
cons:
- Expect layoffs in 2014:
Compensation to health systems by the ACA, CC and Medicare is going WAY down. Upper management has done what it could to mitigate (so they say) but CEO already told management that nobody is safe. The motto of "no layoffs" is no longer true.
 
- No flexibility, culture of bullying & backstabbing that is condoned by HR: 
No flexibility in terms of start time, hours, lunches etc. You are forced to clock in and out for everything you do at the same time each day. You should expect to be tracked/followed and reported on behind your back to HR by fellow employees and even directors.

- Your opinion doesn't matter. Non-technical personnel hired into technical positions:
Most directors across IT/Marcom/Web Center do not care what you think so don't bother voicing it. On top of that, technical departments have non-technical directors making all decisions.

- Scary HR / Marcom propraganda: 
You are force fed how Scripps is a "Great Place to Work". It's a scam - anybody with any quantitative research experience knows that the "survey" results are manipulated in favor of a higher score so they can receive this award each year. Also, the CEO is apparently christ incarnate - everything he says and touches is the word of god.

- Future of IT & Web Center is grim. Best practices? Don't expect to follow them here:
Vendors have access to all production environments including patient data. Their primary EMR, GE Centricity, is so old and unstable that it's only used by 5 clients across the entire country and won't meet government requirements for ACA. Patient portal is unstable and has a scary number of security, usability and customer service issues.

- Low pay, career ending, old power-wielding employees don't enjoy change:
Expect to receive a 15-30% cut in compensation for this market. Many employees have a mentality that Scripps is their career destination. Guess what, you have to appease these people in order to get into their good graces. They don't like change.

-Overall:
This health system is rapidly descending downhill in 2014 with regards to their IT and web technology as well as compensation, time off, and general work environment & culture. Please don't make the worst decision of your life.

review_title: Business Services Department - I wanted to love my job.  However...not happening.
job_title: Business Services in San Diego, CA
pros:
Flexible hours. Love that!! 
Some really great co-workers.
Good Café on site for a while but now they buy processed and sell it higher priced then all the restaurants on the corner.
cons:
Scripps might have a "great place to work" status but the Business Services at 4S is horrible. I've worked here a few years now and the department didn't do well on the 'great place to work' survey so didn't give it to us last year!! It's a new building for Scripps and they are letting it get trashed. It's filthy and poorly maintained. Really.
There is no job training here. Not even job guides that enable you to learn on your own. New hires aren't given even the basics and there is no continuity for how to proceed...it all depends on who you ask because no one is taught procedures.  Going to Epic soon and the super-users who get special training to help the others on the floor are just getting the same class as everyone else but they take it 3 times! Once, again, there won't be anyone who really knows the answers to problems of software or coding or billing or insurance! Turn over is terrible which shows how bad things are because the benefits are good.
Management is unbelievable. They never live by their own rules. They have no idea how to get their job done. Obviously, promotion to that position has nothing to do with expertise and everything to do with 'friends' in high places. Promoted beyond their competence level for sure. Always in meetings but never training or supporting the staff. Sometimes the results are a financial disaster and guess who they blame...They have % raises and job reviews that are a joke. Impossible to excel but managers can make their favorites look good even when they are known to cheat at production and quality. 
There are some good supervisors but the directors and managers are slowly weeding them out...sad.
Can't bring in the $ so they are cutting supplies, services at the employee level. Have to get your toilet paper early in the day! No joke. Can't keep trash cans emptied so they just keep removing them! There aren't any at your desk or in the parking structure any more.
There was a great café there for a couple months but it slowly started serving mostly all previously processed/baked goods and the prices go up and up and up.

job_title: Transporter/Lift Team Technician in San Diego, CA
pros: I worked in the transport/patient logistics department for over a year. The only pros I can think of is working with some wonderful nurses, getting experience in the ICU, and getting to work all over the hospital by transporting patients and getting to know other staff. You also get to work in the ER by transporting patients, so you see a lot of stuff. This is a good place to work if you'd like to get some experience before moving on to another (better) health care organization in San Diego.
cons: HORRIBLE toxic environment created by some employees and, especially, management. Management fosters and embraces this toxicity, and loves to victim blame. Pay is definitely not competitive in San Diego, and does not even closely match up with living wages. HR only cares about blaming "bad apples" and doesn't understand the negative and toxic culture of the Patient Logistics department at Scripps Mercy San Diego. The department also has a notoriously high turnover rate. Oh, and they LOVE to give new hires (instead of senior employees) leadership roles... all that ends up happening is these "leads" will become flustered and overwhelmed, and ask for help from senior staff. I still can't fathom my on earth management does this. It's a very politicized and toxic environment. Management also likes to give you the cold shoulder and subtly retaliate if you go to HR or bring up issues within the department. I would avoid working at Mercy (in the transport department) like the plague, unless you really have no other option to get your foot in the door in a hospital system (at that point I would advise anyone to transfer out after 3 months).

job_title: Anonymous in San Diego, CA
pros: Great vacation and time off benefits, yet one needs to have survived Chris Van Gorders "Lean Green Machine" in order to benefit. This is the reason that administration is stuck with the current promotional policy from within, with current staff members. Which is great in the absence of structural support, ie unions, the staff are left to  work out how to survive in this type of institution. Think "Lord of The Flies".  Forming groups and group social dynamics that ensure one's survival.  Sadly, this is all so very different as to the advertisement in the all  magazines about being in the top 10 greatest hospital systems to work for...
cons: Promotion from within tied to group survival and dynamics designed to ensure survival of the species. The value driven driven BS promoted is just that, along with constant instability due to lack of coordination of a long term plan.  Concretely, the ability for Scripps to form longstanding bridges within the community has faded as their reputation has deteriorated as they continue to implement the same policies that rescued them from previous fallouts that no longer will work as SD area hospitals are changing and growing leaving Scripps in the dust. EX: Kaiser and UCSD, both union and much more competitive. Scripps employees and managers all trying to escape rather then emerge as leaders. Lastly, the rhetoric is inspiring, yet not being actionable within this current environment. Board Members and Management  could benefit from ethical and civic education...

review_title: Not the place it was! Read The 1* reviews!
job_title: Patient Service Representative in San Diego, CA
pros: Read the lower star reviews! No clue who is leaving the 5* reviews... Scripps has been going down hill for the past 3 years and so has the main boss CVG. They fired 75 long term employees of 10-25 years of experience and the very —— I mean very next week —- all brand new furniture in the $100,000s... showed up for CVG and his teams. Uhmmm a little strange don’t you think? Fire people and then build a new floor... hire cheaper people... repeat! Makes me sick!
cons: I have no idea where all the 5* reviews are coming from... Scripps has been a hell hole for years. Bad bosses getting promoted time and time again at the expense of good people! I have been a PSR (patient service rep) in numerous departments and sadly the leadership teams SUCK! There is a pattern here! It’s all over TVe system!  The horrible treatment of staff while leaders blame the employees for not getting things done! Completely unrealistic expectation! Leaders expect PSRs to check in patients, verify insurance, answer phones up to 6 lines at once, call patients to reschedule, help submit referrals with correct icd-10 medical coding, call physician offices, run the office, keep the machines going, fax the doctors office, keep the patient lobby clean, get patient letters ready for mailing, refill prescriptions requests to the numbers, etc. all ——- on one person! All for the bargain price of $13.50/hour. WHAT?!?! And then they threaten you with write ups if anything is missed.  Uhm no thanks. I’ll look for a new you where I am not mastering the art of walking on egg shells 24/7.
